resources.string: The amount by which particles are slowed over time.
Global multiplier for all repulsive and attractive forces.
Global multiplier for the distance at which the repulsive and attractive forces act.
Strength of repulsion when particles get too close.
Simulation time step multiplier. Lower values lead to higher fidelity but slower simulation, higher values lead to faster simulation with more instability.
Enable, disable, or edit manual intervention gestures.
Edit the settings for gestures that allow manual control over the movement of particles.
Swiping on the screen will move particles around.
Force applied to particles while swiping.
Area of effect of swiping force.
Prolonged pressing on the screen will attract particles.
Force applied to particles while pressing.
Distance at which particles will be affected while pressing.
Modify particles, species, and how they interact. These settings only take effect upon generating new particles.
Too many particles will impact simulation performance.
Maximum and minimum values for the distribution of the strengths of forces between species. Positive values indicate attraction and negative values indicate repulsion.
Maximum and minimum values for the distribution of the distances of the forces between species.
Tap a colour to view and edit the force strength from that species\' point of view. Positive values indicate attraction and negative values indicate repulsion.
Tap a colour to view and edit the distance at which the force acts from that species\' point of view. In each case there is a minimum and maximum distance.
Customize and set a live wallpaper
A particle simulation, designed to illustrate life-like behaviour emerging from particles obeying a set of simple rules.

Each particle exerts a force on other nearby particles, depending on their species (represented by the different colours). This can either be a repulsion or an attraction, and is not necessarily symmetric. For example, red can be attracted to green, but green could be repulsed by red, which would result in red \"chasing\" green.

To avoid particles speeding up forever, a global friction is applied that slows particles down. Additionally, all particles repel each other if they get too close for comfort, like a kind of degeneracy pressure
If you feel like you want to give your critters a nudge in the right direction, enable Hand of God to herd (by swiping) or beckon (by pressing) particles to your whim.
Play around with different settings to discover which parameters result in the most \"life-like\" creatures.
An example of the force particles exert based on their distance from each other.
